stimulusHtml: A group of students wishes to experimentally determine the focal length f of a concave (converging) mirror. The students have a lamp and use the mirror to form a focused image of the lamp on a white card. With the lamp located at different positions, the students measure the distance dL between the lamp and the mirror as well as the distance dC between the card and the mirror when the image is in focus on the card. Are these measurements sufficient to determine f? What reasoning helps support the claim?
choicesHtml: No. The image and object heights must also be measured so that the magnification can be determined.
